instructions.p: Be sure to read the instructions and text boxes on each page and click or hover on all buttons.
To begin a different level or course, select from the navigation console menu a the top of your page.
To locate a specific topic in a course, choose from the submenu on the left side of your screen.

transcript.p: At the completion of Level I - Basic ECG - the learner will:

ol.li: Identify heart anatomy, muscle, chambers and vessels.
Describe heart physiology, including conduction pathways.
Differentiate waveform basics and their relationship to anatomy and physiology.
Demonstrate paper basics and heart rate determination.

page.name: Introduction
page.keywords: anatomy physiology beat beats conception organ embryo heart bpm

transcript.p: The human heart... priceless. It begins to beat around the 22nd day after conception and is the first organ to form in the developing embryo. As an adult, the heart beats an average of:

This unbelievable organ will beat without stopping, each and every day of your life without a break or a day off,
3 billion times during an average life span of 80 years.

page.name: Heart Location

instructions.p: Click the blue buttons on the left to remove the structures and expose the heart.
To start over, click the Refresh button.

page.keywords: anatomy physiology heart location locate skin muscle, ribs trachea lungs

transcript.title: Heart Location
transcript.p: The heart is located behind the ribs, between the lungs in the middle of the chest, slightly to the left and closer to the front chest wall.

page.name: Virtual Heart

instructions.p: Click the blue buttons to view the named region of the heart.
Hover your mouse over the heart to watch it rotate and beat.

page.keywords: wall lateral inferior posterior septal anterior rotate heart virtual animated area infarction

question.text: Which area of the heart most commonly experiences an infarction?
question.answer: The inferior wall of the heart.

transcript.title: Heart Location
transcript.p: The heart is a fist sized, pear-shaped muscle. It weighs from 9 to 11 ounces and pumps about 5 quarts of blood through the body every minute. That's almost 2,000 gallons of blood a day!
Identifying the different regions of the heart is important because these locations relate to the 12 lead ECG. In this depiction, each region is colored coded as follows:

page.name: Heart Structures
page.keywords: atria atrium ventricle vessel oxygen vein artery superior vena cava tricuspid valve mitral aorta pulmonary

question.text: What two vessels are considered to be the 'great vessels' and why??
question.answer: The two great vessels are the Aorta and the Pulmonary Artery because they receive blood pumped from the right and left ventricles.

ol.li: A sophisticated network of vessels connects with the heart and lungs so that the entire body can be maintained and sustained with oxygen rich blood.
Arteries carry oxygenated blood away from the heart, while veins return unoxygenated blood to the heart.
Note that the superior vena cava returns blood from the head and arms while the inferior vena cava returns blood from the trunk and legs.
Unoxygenated blood enters the heart filling the right atrium passing through the tricuspid valve into the right ventricle.
It is pumped out of the right ventricle through the pulmonary artery and into the lungs where it is re-oxygenated.

Next the pulmonary vein receives oxygenated blood and fills the left atrium, passes through the mitral valve into the left ventricle, where it is pumped out to the body through the aorta, the largest artery in the body.
